overview: The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit. [13] It also establishes a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] The Act requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [13]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026. [13] An additional $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] The funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [13]
agency_impact: The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [13] This measure establishes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [13]
economic_impact: The program's goal is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [13]
policy_impact: This measure makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [14] It codifies the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit within the Hawaii Revised Statutes, rather than the Session Laws of Hawaii. [14] The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit is changed from three years to two years, with a sunset date of June 30, 2027. [14] [14]
revenue_sources: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sums for the purposes of this Act. [13] [13]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot program. [13] These funds cover mental health, substance abuse treatment, services, equipment, and one temporary (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [13] [13] The pilot program established in Part III of the act is repealed on June 30, 2027. [13] The judiciary is required to submit a report to the legislature with recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should continue as a pilot program, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [13] The women's court program in the first circuit is permanently established, which will have ongoing fiscal implications beyond the pilot program, but specific funding is not appropriated in this Act. [13] [13]
capital_expenditure_impact: Appropriated funds will be used for equipment for the women's court pilot program, although specific capital expenditures are not detailed. [13]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Part III of the Act, which establishes the pilot program and its associated appropriations, shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13] The permanent establishment of the women's court program in the first circuit will have ongoing fiscal obligations. [13] Any ongoing fiscal implications for the Kona program will depend on legislative action following the Judiciary's final report and recommendations in 2027. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: While the previous fiscal note indicated unspecified appropriations, this measure appropriates specific sums; the committee hearing determines $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [14] This measure requires the Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services, whereas the prior note mentioned a Department of Health funding request. [14] The duration of the Kona pilot program has been changed from three years to two years, and language that would have required a report on expansion to other circuits was deleted. [14] [14]
